Yes, but only if they have been in the US for at least 14 days. 

If you are not a citizen of the United States, you can apply for a work-visa waiver from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) at https://www.dhs.gov/documents/coronavirus-relief-requirements.pdf. It is important to note that the DHS does not have the authority to issue such a waiver, so it is best to contact your local law enforcement agency to find out what they are doing about it. You can find more information on how DHS issues work visas here.
The DHS has also issued guidance to nonimmigrants who are claimed as a dependent of a US citizen or permanent resident (as defined in section 212(a)(9)(B)(iv)(I)), as well as to individuals who were claimed by a nonimmigrant spouse or dependent on Form I-94, as of March 30, 2020, and are otherwise entitled to a Social Security Number (SSN) for purposes of eligibility for the payment of any tax imposed by this Act on the taxpayer’s adjusted gross income over the tax year in which they claimed the alienation, whichever is later. The guidance also provides that you may not be claimed for any refund under section 505(g)(2)(A)(ii)(II) if you fail to file your tax return within 90 days after the end of your 14-day period of claimed status, unless the Secretary determines that your return is not timely filed. If you do not meet the requirements of this subsection, your application will be considered nonfrivolous and you will not receive a refund. However, if your claim is for an extension of stay or change of status (for which you did not file a timely return), you must file the return as soon as possible after your status is no longer valid. For more on this, see How do I file my return if I am a claimed alien? 


You may still be able to claim the Extension of Status Extension (FOI) waiver under the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101 et seq.), but the process for doing so is different than for COVID-19. See the section entitled "Exemptions for Certain Aliens who Are Dependent on or Are Residing in a Country with a Suspended or Canceled Federal, State, or Local Law Enforcement Act of 1948" for more details. Under the Act, an alien who is claimed under this provision is subject to the following conditions:   (1) The alien has not been physically present within the Schengen Area for 14 calendar days prior to his or her claim,
(2) He or she is a bona fide resident alien (i.e., a "nonimmigrant alien"),
  and (3) Upon expiration of such alien's stay, the application was not filed inadmissible or falsified in any way, except as provided in subsection (e)(3).
However, in order to get a stay of INA 222 (relating to aliens who have not yet claimed their status), a person must have filed and been properly present at the time the claim was filed with the USCIS. In addition, any alien claiming to be a DI or EOS or alien with permanent residence status who was unlawfully present during the 14 day period preceding the date of claim application must submit a written explanation of why he/she did so, including any evidence of prior unauthorized entry or attempted entry, proof of citizenship or lawful re-entry, a copy of an identification document, documentation of non-custodial parent(s) or legal guardian(ies), and any other form of evidence necessary to support the claimed purpose for claiming the status. A nonrefundable tax credit of up to $500 is available for nonfilers who file their tax returns after April 15 of 2020 and before April 30 of 2021. This credit is limited to amounts that are forgiven by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Tax Code"), which was enacted to provide relief for filers with pre-tax incomes over $75,000 and after July 1, 2021, which were not refundable during that calendar year. To qualify for this credit, one must be filing and had a valid work authorization (such as an ESTA) and have a residence permit issued by another state or territory. Once the credit has been applied for, it cannot be used to pay any additional taxes, credits or other payments, such as refunds or extensions of tax benefits, until the next taxable year begins.

Yes, but only if you are planning to travel to or from the US. 

You should contact your travel agent and ask if they will allow you to board the flight, and if so, how long you will be allowed to stay at the airport. You should also check to make sure you have all the necessary documents, including your Social Security Number, your passport and any insurance you may have. If you do not have insurance, you should ask your insurance company to cover the cost of the trip.
If you need to cancel your trip, it is possible to do so by phone or online. However, this is not guaranteed, as the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has a process in place to prevent telephonic cancellations and other disruptions of international flights, so be sure to check your carrier's policies for any restrictions on this kind of travel.


  Does the travel ban apply to all US citizens or residents who have been in the Schengen area for at least 14 days?
No. The ban does not affect US residents or nonimmigrants who entered the EU through the UK or Ireland. It only applies to people who arrived in or attempted to enter the United States during the 14-day period preceding their entry, regardless of whether they had a valid US-issued travel document and were not claimed as a "green card holder". 



  What is the legal basis for a travel restriction that prevents me from traveling to, or entering, the U.S. for the following reasons:
I have a medical condition that requires me to self-isolate in order to care for my family, my partner and my child; I have recently been diagnosed with COVID-19; or I am in a state of undiagnosed or suspected illness that renders my health condition worse than that of my spouse or family member; My child is in need of care or care-related services that are essential to the child’s well-being; The child has been placed in an institution of higher education or training that is substantially equivalent to a public institution in terms of skills and knowledge that would be required for an employee of a comparable level of education; A child who is physically or mentally incapacitated would pose a risk of serious harm to myself or others if I were to exercise my rights under the law to leave my home, work, school, religious practice or other public or private sector activities; An alien with a history of domestic or international violence or child endangerment who presents with symptoms consistent with the severity of illness or the likelihood of future illness;
My spouse is a US citizen or permanent resident and has not been physically present within the last 30 days. Does this mean that I will not be able to visit my children at home? Or is it possible that the children will continue to attend school in accordance with my domestic and international obligations, even if my wife is unable to return to her home country after the 30 day period of absence? If yes, what rights are there to visitation and visitation rights for children who are not yet in school? Is this a legal right or a political right? Does visitation or visitation be considered a form of child support? What are the rights and responsibilities of an unmarried parent in relation to their child visitation? Are there any legal rights or responsibilities for unmarried parents who wish to continue their children's education, research or research activities outside of their household? I would like to know if there are any federal, state or local laws or regulations that specifically address this aspect of visitation, such as visitation orders, visitation decrees, child custody orders or any other legal or regulatory measures that may be necessary to protect children from harm caused by the visitation order. I understand that some states and local governments have enacted statutes or ordinances that explicitly address these issues, e.g. Illinois has enacted a law that prohibits the "unlawful presence of aliens" (i.e. non-citizens) in certain circumstances, while other states have not. Is there a federal or state court system that can issue such orders? Do these orders have to be enforced by a local or national law enforcement agency or by an individual with authority to enforce them? How can I contact my attorney about these matters? Any guidance or legal advice I can provide regarding this issue should be directed to my state attorney general, not the F.D.C., and should include guidance on how to proceed in civil cases arising out of or related to this matter. Do I still have legal standing to sue my ex-partner for wrongful termination if he or she is found to have caused the harm that caused him or her to harm himself or herself in violation of this order? Should I file a lawsuit in federal court to try to get the government to compensate me for this harm? (I am not a party to any of these proceedings, however, I do have the right to seek compensatory and punitive damages in addition to damages for intentional infliction of emotional distress or loss of liberty.)

It’s possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can be passed from one person to another through droplets from the nose or mouth, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. However, the CDC recommends that people stay home if they feel unwell and cough or sneeze into their elbow or other area of the body.
 If you have symptoms, call your doctor or local health department and seek medical attention, said Dr. Jennifer Griffin, a coronavirus expert at the George Washington University School of Medicine. She said the best way to protect yourself is to avoid touching your face, mouth or eyes, and to wash your hands with soap and water before and after you leave the hospital. You can also use an alcohol-based hand rub or a hand sanitizer to help ease the symptoms. But if you're worried that you might be sick, use a product that contains at least 60 percent alcohol and is safe to use, Griffin said. [See How to Wash Your Hands with Alcohol-Based Hand Rub](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/25/health/coronaviruse-hand-rub.html) and use it at home instead of at a pharmacy or drugstore, she added.  
  “If you are sick and want to get medical help, you should talk to your health care provider about using products that are safe and effective for you and your family,” Griffin told Mother Jones. The CDC has also developed a list of products and services that can help people with respiratory illnesses, including masks, gowns, gloves, face shields, eye protection and face masks. For more information about how to safely wear a mask, see How to Protect Yourself from Illness and Currently, there is no evidence to suggest that the coronavirus can be stopped or reversed.  The only way to prevent or reverse the virus from spreading is to use good respiratory hygiene and avoid touching your face, nose or mouth.

However, it is important to maintain at least 1 metre (3 feet) distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing. If you are too close, you should wash your hands with soap and water, cover your cough with a tissue and throw the tissue in the trash. Follow the directions of local authorities and health authorities on how to dispose of discarded tissue, including the local authority for disposing of it. You should also carry a disinfectant bottle with you when you leave the house, to help protect you and your loved ones from viruses that may be spreading around your house. The best disinfectants are those that are commonly used in homes and businesses, such as Bleach and Bleach Plus, which are often used to disinfect household cleaners and other household items. I am a PhD student in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Waterloo. I have been working on an open source software development framework for distributed systems engineering (DSE). The framework is based on the COVID-19 model, which is a dynamic distributed system model that can be used to predict the future behavior of systems. It has been tested on Linux, Mac OS X, and Linux distributions. In this blog post I will show you how to use the framework to build a simulation program to model the evolution of a system. You can download the code from github here: https://github.com/wilsoncovid19/COVID19Simulator/blob/master/csgo/cgo.go#L8
You can find the source code in this repository:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Project_of_the_20%E2%80%9320_World_War_II_Programming_Strategy_in_Cyber-Assisted_Mechanical_Dynamics_with_Infected_by_Organized_Coronaviruses_and_CoV_Wuhan
The simulation code is available on github:   http://docs.google.co.uk/forms/d/dlg/events/view/index.cfm?key=key&source=view&ct=default>u=&v=1&tid=19&sig=cgv2&q=CGE_19_Simulation_Data&cdg=0&vb=https%3A%2F% 2F.aft.uiv.wa.ac.ca%26facepartment%27skeynote%28%29.pdf

If you have some ideas, please feel free to forward them to me.

 You can get tested for the virus if someone in your household tests positive for it.
